Well, the federal funds rate, the rate that the Federal Reserve gets to set, is the most basic interest rate in the economy.
And at a very basic level, it determines the cost of funds for banks that then make loans or fund other types of loans in the economy.
But of course, we don't pay the same rate that the Fed sets.

And the problem, of course, with the economy over the past year or so is that while the Fed has been bringing down the federal funds rate, those actual borrowing rates that we - you and I - pay, those haven't been coming down, or haven't been coming down anything like as fast, because the risk premium on lending has been going up.
Why would the Fed keep dropping the benchmark rate if it's really not working?
Well, you have to remember what the counterfactual is.
If they hadn't cut the benchmark rate, but the risk spreads had just gone up, then interest rates would be even higher than they are today for you and me.
So reducing the fed funds rate hasn't been a waste of time.
It's been able to cushion the blow.
But it hasn't been able itself to solve the underlying problem, which is that these risk spreads on loans have gone up as banks have become extremely reluctant to lend to anybody.
Have the banks been receptive at all to the news that the benchmark rate may go down, maybe as far as zero?
Well, at this point, the interest rate is going to end up quite close to zero.
Whether it ends up at zero or not is a second-order issue.
The big game now is about all the other things the Federal Reserve is trying to do to support the economy.
What it's doing is it's going out and making very large-scale loans to financial institutions.
It's trying to support financial markets, for instance, by buying short-term IOUs.
And it's actually going out and buying mortgage-related securities issued by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to try and drive down home loan rates.
In the course of doing all of this, it's swelling the size of its balance sheet and pumping lots of reserves into the banking system.
But at this point, the non-interest rate tools are becoming more and more important compared with where the federal funds rate is actually set.
What about that half-point cut?
Would it mean anything for the global economy if it happens?
Well, the dollar is the world's reserve currency.
The demand for dollars has escalated around the world.
Everyone wants dollars.
And what's more, they want cash.
So by reducing the fed funds rate, the Federal Reserve can help not only the U.S.
economy, but also the financial systems and the economies of other countries around the world.
And of course, in the long run, the more stable the banking systems are outside the U.S., the more support the U.S.
economy will get from world trade.
And at a time when the U.S.
is very weak, the U.S.
needs all the help it can get from exports.

More than three months after Hurricane Katrina, thousands of families remain far from home and they're working to rebuild new lives in unfamiliar cities.
It's especially hard during the holiday season.
Joshua Levs has followed the Smith family ever since they fled New Orleans just before the storm.
This week, he visited them at their new home in McKinney, Texas.
We're driving through the busy streets of McKinney, a city of about 100,000 people, a 45-minute ride north from Dallas.
Chiquita and Selwyn Smith have gotten pretty good at navigating the area, though they say driving in McKinney is very different from driving in New Orleans.
It does not compare.
They say the pace of life feels different.
I don't know, like everybody's in a rush, trying to hurry to get home.
They're getting used to Texas life and like some expressions they hear.
`Bless your heart.'
(Soundbite of laughter)
I recognize that one.
`Bless you heart, darlin'.
I like that.
They've also come to like the famous Texas pride.
Yeah, the pride here, that's what I like.
And I wish people in New Orleans would have that, I really do.
We pull up to their house on a quiet residential street of brick homes with small front lawns.
This is our entryway.
This is our--like, a little office, and the kids can do their homework and...
It's a spacious single-story house with a large living room and three bedrooms.
They have some furniture that Selwyn brought back from New Orleans.
He says it helps them all feel a little more comfortable.
If your house--you know, if some of the things at your house are still from there, you got some of your furniture, you know, that helps out.
There's a nice leather couch that was among furniture locals donated to Katrina evacuees, and against the wall, a Christmas tree, about six feet tall, donated by a nearby church.
And then they donated decorations and stuff like that, so, you know, decorate the tree as well.
There are presents beneath the tree.
The Smiths saved money for gifts for their three children and their niece who's living with them.
In the best of times, Christmas can be difficult for people in a new city.
After all the Smiths have gone through, they want as normal a holiday as possible.
They're not religious, and Christmas Day is also Selwyn's birthday.
In New Orleans, they would celebrate with friends and relatives.
